data.title: CONTENTdm
data.meta_description:
James Cavanaugh interviews Ruth Doyle on January 4, 1985. Doyle discusses her personal and political background, her election to the Assembly in 1948, her defeat in 1952 for state treasurer, her service on both the Dane County board and school board in the 1950s and 1960s, the Democratic Organizing Committee (DOC), her husband James Doyle's political and legal career, the roles and challenges of women in politics, and how the Democratic Party has changed since the 1940s. Among the political figures Doyle mentions are Dan Hoan, Carl Thompson, Horace Wilkie, Bob Tehan, Harry Truman, Joe McCarthy, Packy McParland, Vernon Thomson, and Warren Smith.

This interview is part of the Wisconsin Democratic Party Oral History Project.
